children.subject:
I think it depends on your mathematical maturity. 61c is a huge time-sink so as long as you don't need to spend massive amounts of time understanding 126 ideas you should be fine.

I would recommend thinking about 61c and 170 together if you are looking to do a systems and theory course combo. I think 170 is taught with an understanding that students are still getting comfortable with proofs and arguments while 126 more or less expects you to be fluent in proof based math.

history.content:
Very manageable.

R5B really depends on your professor and your writing style, the workload could be as much as an elective or as much as a tech.

Econ 1 is really on par with an elective, so no worries about that.

61C has a heavy workload. But you do well on CS61A/B, you should be fine.

126 has a decent workload but with many theoretical parts. But you do well on 70, you should be fine.

A workload for EECS is often 1 heavy tech + 2 techs + 1 elective. So yours seems very manageable. The only caveat is in the next semester, you suddenly find 61C, 126, Econ 1 harder than any other classes you have taken. I think it's unlikely, but you can browse the syllabus or some problem sets to make a self-evaluation.

Very manageable.

R5B really depends on your professor and your writing style, the workload could be as much as an elective or as much as a tech.

Econ 1 is really on par with an elective, so no worries about that.

61C has a heavy workload, so it's heavy technical. But you do well on CS61A/B, you should be fine.

126 has a decent workload but with many theoretical parts. But you do well on 70, you should be fine.

A workload for EECS is often 1 heavy tech + 2 techs + 1 elective. So it seems very manageable. The only caveat is you suddenly find 61C, 126, Econ 1 harder than any other classes you have taken. I think it's unlikely, but you can browse the syllabus or some problem sets to make a self-evaluation.

<md>I was wondering if the workload of 61C + 126 would be manageable. I've heard that the workload of 61C is higher in the Spring - can anyone who's previously taken the class confirm/deny this? 

For reference, I'm also taking Econ 1 and an R5B. 70 has been decently manageable for me so far, and I did well in 61A/B.</md>
history.subject: 61C + 126?
